data: Horizontal guidelines between lines, but almost no interlineation. The text maintains left and right margins (with guideline indicating an outer right margin), with words broken across lines or abbreviated to maintain the margins. Interpuncts mark the ends of lines 2 and 3.
Tall narrow letters with pronounced serifs and curved horizontal feet to vertical strokes.

I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; courtesy  Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas; photo J.Prag 23.05.22
Manganaro, 1989, Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia

Funerary inscription for Publius Edusius Basilides
Four lines of Latin, first line cnetred, lines 2-4 with consistent left margin; guidelines visible top and bottom of each line.
Deep cut letters simple serifs, simply cut, moderate width module.
L'année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l'antiquité romaine., 1888-
Muscolino, 2011-2012, Epigrafi funerarie greche e latine di Taormina
funerary inscription for publius edusius basilides

1d(is) m(anibus) s(acrum)
2P(ublius) Edusius Ba-
3silides vix(it)
4ann(is) XXXXV
Three lines of Latin letters, filling the surface of the stone, maintaining left and right margins.
Letters are relatively shallow v-cut, with terminal serifs and oval interpuncts, and some signs of cursive influence. Note the ligature in line 2 (NI) and the very ornate G and E.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana: photo J. Prag 13-07-2022

1Auctario ·
2Primigen͡i · f(ilio) ·
3[vi]x̣(it) · ạṇ(nis) XXI ·
Three lines of Latin letters, decreasing in size and only approximately centred on the stone, with each line starting a little further to the right.
Neat v-cut letters with pronounced serifs and several extravagant forms (very extended Y, CH in distinctive ligature), triangular interpuncts.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-06.

1Caninia

Fragmentary funerary inscription for a member of the gens Coponia
Ferrua records the presence of a hedera in the line 1 heading.
fragmentary funerary inscription for a member of the gens coponia

1D(is) ❦ [M(anibus)]
2Copo[ni ---]

Three lines of Latin text, centred on the stone, with the header of line 1 filling the upper half of the stone. Interpuncts only used in final line, and do not follow a consistent pattern (first visible interpunct is shaped like a tight comma, second like a diagonal slash, third like a larger comma, final like a downwards slash).
Letters are tall and precise. There are simple, but standard, serifs on all letters. P is very open, T and L have wavy cross bars.
later 2nd century CE (Ferrua on the basis of the letter forms)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-05.

1d(is) m(anibus)
2Coponia Am-
3[em]ta · v(ixit) · an(nis) · L ·
Four complete lines of Latin text approximately centred
Text is shallowly incised, irregular and rough. Letters are not straight, nor in line with each other. Very basic serifs, on occasional letters. Long tail on "L" in line 4.
Ferrua dates to the fourth century on the basis of the lettering.
Castelli, 1769, Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio
Castelli, 1784, Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio prolegomenis et notis illustrata, et iterum cum emendationibus, & auctariis evulgata

1d(is) m(anibus)
2Cornelius
3Acathobu-
4s vix(it) ann(is) LV
Four lines of Latin text, all incomplete. Line 1 is almost impossible to recover. Block-shaped interpuncts

Text is extremely ill-defined and shallowly inscribed into stone. Letters are irregular in height, consistency and lean in different directions, although the final line is less irregular than the rest. Serifs evident on some letters.
irrecoverable on the basis of the bottoms of letter forms alone

4[enus] [vi]xit · an(nis) · XLV ·
Notable that the text, as recorded by Ferrua appears to lack care in disposition, with words broken across line end on every line after the first.
Ferrua dates to the 4th century CE, presumably on the basis of the letter forms.

4nis III mensi-
5bus II
Three lines of Latin letters, seemingly maintaining a consistent left margin, but irregular right margin, with a large vacat after DMS in line 1.
Deep cut letters, with extended apices and somewhat irregular in layout and size. Deep serifs and occasional hederae but no interpuncts.
Ferrua dates to the 3rd century CE on the basis of the letter forms.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-04

1D(is) m(anibus) s(acrum)
2Euplia ❦ vị-
3xit ❦ an(nis) (())(circiter?) LV
Three lines of Latin text, not centred, but slightly over to right. Use of hederae in line three.
Letters have serifs. Depth of letter incision decreases from left to right, and line 2 is particularly lightly incised. Letters well-spaced, except for the final few letters of line three.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

Text over four lines, lines 1, 3, 4 share the same left margin, line 2 begins further to the left.
Letters with a fluid / curving stroke, extensions to strokes and/or serirfs, R is open.

The text is approximately centered on the stone, with the left and right margins more or less regular except in the final two lines.
Ferrua suggested early 3rd century CE, Griffo the  1st century CE; a date in the first two centuries CE seems likely (so also Bitto 2001: 71).
